label: Mentored
evidence: Andreae dedicated works to Hess including De Christiani Cosmoxeni genitura (1612). He wrote a memorial for Hess when he died in 1614 and referred to him in glowing terms as a mentor and father-figure.

label: Mentored
evidence: Besold encouraged Andreae's interest in esotericism and provided access to his large personal library of mystical and philosophical sources. They were close colleagues in the Tübingen Circle.

label: Spiritual influence
evidence: Andreae highly praised True Christianity and published Christianismus genuinus (1615) as a summary of Arndt's treatise. Arndt's practical spirituality deeply shaped Andreae's theological vision.

label: Close friends
evidence: Besold and Kepler were classmates at the University of Tübingen in the early 1590s. When Kepler's mother was accused of witchcraft in 1615, Besold helped in her legal defense.

label: Studied astronomy
evidence: Kepler studied at the University of Tübingen under Mästlin, who introduced him to Copernican astronomy. Mästlin was one of the few supporters of Copernicus at the time.

label: Studied mathematics
evidence: Andreae studied under Michael Mästlin at the University of Tübingen, placing him in the same intellectual context as Kepler.

label: Posthumous influence
evidence: Weigel's posthumously published writings on inner spirituality and the 'inner church' influenced Boehme's development of Christian theosophy.

label: Posthumous influence
evidence: Weigel's mystical writings influenced Arndt's devotional theology and emphasis on inner transformation.

label: Posthumous influence
evidence: Boehme adopted alchemical symbols and the Paracelsian three principles (salt, sulfur, mercury) to articulate his nature mysticism.

label: Spiritual influence
evidence: Franck's emphasis on the inner Word over external Scripture and doctrine influenced Weigel's development of spiritualist thought.

label: Spiritual influence
evidence: Schwenckfeld's works were collected by Karl Widemann and his spiritualist emphasis influenced Weigel's thought.

label: Posthumous influence
evidence: Gichtel was a major follower of Boehme who edited and published Boehme's collected works and founded the Gichtelians based on Boehme's teachings.

label: Angelic communications
evidence: Dee and Kelley collaborated on spiritual conferences and angelic communications from 1582. They traveled together through Central Europe seeking patronage until parting in 1589.

label: Met in Bremen
evidence: Khunrath met John Dee in Bremen on 27 May 1589 as Dee was returning to England. Khunrath later praised Dee in his writings.

label: Met at Prague court
evidence: After meeting Dee, Khunrath traveled to Rudolf II's court in Prague where he met Edward Kelley who had remained in Bohemia.

label: Received at court
evidence: Dee and Kelley first made contact with Rudolf II in Prague in 1583, seeking patronage for their esoteric work.

label: Court alchemist
evidence: After parting from Dee, Kelley remained in Bohemia as a prominent alchemist under Rudolf II's patronage until his imprisonment and death.

label: Physician and counselor
evidence: On 19 September 1609 Maier formally entered the service of Emperor Rudolf II as his physician and imperial counselor. He was elevated to hereditary nobility.

label: Imperial Astronomer
evidence: Tycho Brahe became Imperial Court Astronomer under Rudolf II in Prague from 1599 until his death in 1601.

label: Imperial Mathematician
evidence: Kepler succeeded Tycho Brahe as Imperial Astronomer under Rudolf II after Brahe's death in 1601.

label: Astronomical collaboration
evidence: Kepler joined Brahe as an assistant in Prague in 1600 and inherited his observational data after Brahe's death in 1601.

label: Hosted at Třeboň
evidence: Vilém of Rožmberk hosted John Dee and Edward Kelley at his castle in Třeboň, supporting their alchemical research.

label: Alchemical patron
evidence: Vilém of Rožmberk was a major patron of Edward Kelley at his castle in Třeboň.

label: Secretary
evidence: Karl Widemann briefly served as secretary to Edward Kelley at Rudolf II's court in Prague.

label: Intellectual polemic
evidence: Libavius published Analysis Confessionis (1615) criticizing the Rosicrucian manifestos. Fludd responded with Apologia Compendiaria (1616) and Tractatus Apologeticus (1617) defending the Brotherhood.

label: Appointed first chemistry professor
evidence: In 1609, Landgrave Moritz appointed Hartmann to a newly created chair for Chymiatrie at the University of Marburg—the first professorship explicitly dedicated to chemistry.

label: Court physician
evidence: Around 1619 Maier became physician to Landgrave Moritz of Hesse-Kassel.

label: Close association
evidence: Haslmayr had close ties to Benedictus Figulus and Karl Widemann and reportedly lived with them for a time.

label: Close association
evidence: Haslmayr had close ties to Karl Widemann and reportedly lived with them for a time.

label: Manuscript network
evidence: Figulus and Widemann were both active in collecting and preserving Paracelsian and esoteric manuscripts.

label: Rosicrucian initiation
evidence: Backhouse is reputed to have initiated Ashmole into Rosicrucian and alchemical knowledge around 1651.

label: Married
evidence: Frederick V married Elizabeth Stuart, daughter of King James I of England, in 1613.

label: Court connections
evidence: Maier had ties to Frederick V's court in Heidelberg as part of the Rosicrucian milieu.

label: Garden designer
evidence: Salomon de Caus designed the Hortus Palatinus at Heidelberg for Frederick V from 1611-1619.

label: Published works
evidence: Bodenstein published over 40 Paracelsian titles beginning in 1560, making Paracelsian texts widely available.

label: Brothers
evidence: Conrad Khunrath was the older brother of Heinrich Khunrath.

label: Principal author
evidence: Andreae is generally credited as the main author of the Fama Fraternitatis, though drawing on ideas from Tobias Hess and the Tübingen Circle.

label: Inspired content
evidence: Hess's ideas on Paracelsianism, chiliasm, and reformation echo throughout the Fama. He is seen as the catalyst/inspirer of the manifestos.

label: Principal author
evidence: Andreae is credited as principal author of the Confessio Fraternitatis.
Andreae explicitly acknowledged writing the Chymical Wedding of Christian Rosenkreutz.
Andreae wrote the utopian work Christianopolis.
Aurora was Boehme's first mystical work, written in 1612 and circulated in manuscript.
Boehme wrote Mysterium Magnum in 1623 as a mystical commentary on Genesis.
Gichtel edited and published Boehme's collected works, helping establish Boehme's enduring influence.
Arndt's Vier Bücher vom wahren Christentum was published in four books between 1605 and 1610.
Khunrath wrote Amphitheatrum Sapientiae Aeternae in 1595.
Maier published Atalanta Fugiens in 1617 in Oppenheim.
Croll wrote Basilica Chymica, published in 1609.
Fludd wrote Utriusque Cosmi Historia, published 1617-1621.
Fludd wrote Apologia Compendiaria in 1616 defending the Rosicrucian Brotherhood.
Dee wrote Monas Hieroglyphica in 1564.
Libavius wrote Alchymia in 1597, considered the first systematic chemistry textbook.
Libavius published Analysis Confessionis Fraternitatis de Rosea Cruce in 1615.
Ashmole compiled and published Theatrum Chemicum Britannicum in 1652.
Severinus wrote Idea Medicinae Philosophicae in 1571.

label: English translation
evidence: Thomas Vaughan, under pseudonym Eugenius Philalethes, translated the Fama and Confessio into English in 1652.

label: English translation
evidence: Thomas Vaughan translated the Confessio into English in 1652.

label: Defense against critique
evidence: Fludd's Apologia was written as a response to Libavius's Analysis attacking the Rosicrucian manifestos.

label: Critique
evidence: Libavius's Analysis was a systematic critique of the Confessio Fraternitatis.
Boehme lived and worked as a shoemaker in Görlitz from around 1599 until his death in 1624.

label: University studies
evidence: Andreae studied at the University of Tübingen and was part of the Tübingen Circle.
Hess was a jurist residing in Tübingen.

label: Professor of law
evidence: Besold was professor of law at the University of Tübingen.

label: University student
evidence: Kepler studied at the University of Tübingen.

label: Professor
evidence: Mästlin was professor of mathematics at the University of Tübingen.
Rudolf II made Prague his principal residence and center of his court.
Dee visited Prague seeking patronage from Rudolf II between 1583 and 1589.
Kelley remained in Prague and Bohemia after Dee's departure until his death.
Brahe moved to Prague in 1599 as Imperial Astronomer and died there in 1601.

label: Imperial Astronomer
evidence: Kepler worked in Prague as assistant to Brahe and then as Imperial Astronomer.
Maier moved to Prague in 1608 and served Rudolf II until around 1611.
Khunrath visited Rudolf II's court in Prague where he met Edward Kelley.
Frederick V's court was at Heidelberg from his succession in 1610 until he accepted the Bohemian crown.
Elizabeth Stuart lived at Heidelberg after her marriage to Frederick V in 1613.

label: Garden design
evidence: De Caus designed the Hortus Palatinus at Heidelberg from 1611-1619.

label: Chemistry professor
evidence: Hartmann was appointed professor of Chymiatrie at Marburg in 1609, the first such position.

label: Professor
evidence: Croll was a professor at Marburg.

label: Professor
evidence: Eglin became professor at Marburg from 1606 after fleeing Zürich.
Moritz was Landgrave of Hesse with his court at Kassel.
Fludd practiced medicine in London.
Ashmole lived and worked in London as an antiquarian.
Widemann was a physician based in Augsburg who conducted his manuscript collecting activities there.

label: Exile court
evidence: After his defeat, Frederick V spent the rest of his life in exile at The Hague.

label: Exile court
evidence: Elizabeth Stuart maintained court culture in exile at The Hague for decades after 1622.
Dee and Kelley were hosted by Vilém of Rožmberk at his castle in Třeboň.
Kelley lived at Vilém of Rožmberk's castle in Třeboň conducting alchemical work.

label: Publishing
evidence: Bodenstein worked in Basel publishing Paracelsian texts.

label: Medical degree
evidence: Maier earned his medical doctorate from the University of Basel in October 1596.

label: Intellectual circle
evidence: Mögling was connected to Andreae's intellectual circle and wrote Rosicrucian works in the same period.

label: Posthumous influence
evidence: Sennert sought to reconcile traditional Galenic medicine with Paracelsian innovations, integrating chemical remedies into academic medicine.

label: Thematic parallels
evidence: Bacon's New Atlantis (1627) has been linked to Rosicrucian ideals by scholars like Frances Yates. His project for advancement of learning aligned with manifesto themes, though direct involvement is debated.

label: Tübingen Circle
evidence: Hölzel was part of the wider Tübingen network of mystical and esoteric thinkers that included Andreae, Hess, and Besold.

label: Tübingen Circle member
evidence: Hölzel was associated with the Tübingen Circle centered at the university.

label: Patron and associate
evidence: Von Wense was a noble patron connected to esoteric and utopian circles including the Tübingen network around Andreae.

label: Mentor and father-in-law
evidence: Petraeus was Hartmann's son-in-law and collaborated with him at Marburg in presiding over academic disputations on Paracelsian medicine.

label: Son-in-law
evidence: Petraeus married Hartmann's daughter.

label: Academic
evidence: Petraeus worked at the University of Marburg, presiding over academic disputations.
Cramer wrote Societas Jesu et Rosae Crucis Vera, published by Lucas Jennis of Frankfurt in 1617.

label: Professor
evidence: Cramer held an academic position as professor at the University of Marburg, where he also wrote metaphysical works.

label: Publisher
evidence: Lucas Jennis of Frankfurt published Cramer's Rosicrucian emblem book in 1617.

label: Contemporary emblem authors
evidence: Both Cramer and Maier published Rosicrucian-themed emblem books in 1617 through Frankfurt publishers. Maier's Atalanta Fugiens and Cramer's Societas Jesu et Rosae Crucis Vera represent the flowering of Rosicrucian emblematic literature.

label: Published during furor
evidence: Cramer's 1617 emblem book was part of the wave of Rosicrucian publications that followed the manifestos.
